awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SHINE: Laboratory, Observational, and Modeling Investigations of the Torus Instability and Associated Solar Corona Eruptive Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will extend understanding of solar corona plasmas beyond what is possible using single approaches, such as just analyzing data, just modeling, or just doing experiments.  The cross-checking and discussion of these different approaches will provide a robust means for getting to the heart of the matter and finding out what is really going on.  By reconciling first-principle models, experiments, and analysis of observations, there is an excellent prospect of achieving long-sought insights and improved understanding regarding underlying solar eruption mechanisms.  This 3-year collaborative SHINE project would yield: (i) improved understanding of solar corona global phenomena since eruptions impact the remainder of the solar corona by shedding magnetic energy, magnetic helicity, and plasma particles; (ii) improved understanding of phenomena associated with eruptions such as energetic particles and electromagnetic radiation spanning from radio waves to gamma rays; (iii) improved understanding of the terrestrial impact of eruptions such as the effects on the magnetosphere and ionosphere, on radio propagation, and on spacecraft; (iv) increased public interest in solar physics, because of the highly visual nature of the experiments, the observations, and the numerical modeling; and, (v) training of students in solar and plasma physics and supporting a young female researcher.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

The main goal of this 3-year collaborative SHINE project is to combine laboratory experiments, analysis of data from actual solar eruptions, and numerical modeling of the fundamental magnetohydrodynamics (MHD).  Laboratory plasmas having morphology and dynamics similar to solar plasmas will be studied by at Caltech.  This study is feasible because MHD has no intrinsic scale so MHD laboratory plasmas having dimensionless numbers and morphology similar to the solar corona will exhibit similar behavior, but on much different temporal and spatial scales.  The analysis of actual solar eruptions and CME kinematics will be performed at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.  This analysis will focus on the magnetic field structural properties in and above the source regions of eruptions.  The analysis will apply non-linear force-free extrapolations based on magnetogram data obtained from spacecraft, such as Hinode and SDO, so as to calculate the strapping field profile as a function of altitude and core magnetic field.  The dependence of CME acceleration profile and final speed on the decay index will be analyzed and compared to the experiments and to the numerical models developed at Predictive Science Inc.  The project team will compare numerical predictions to both the laboratory experiments and the solar eruption analysis.  This comparison will take into account both the strapping field decay index and morphological changes of erupting flux ropes due to kinking.

por.por_cntn:
The solar atmosphere displays a large variety of eruptive phenomena, ranging from relatively small explosive events, such as nano-flares, up to large X-class flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which can propel magnetic fields and huge amounts of plasma into interplanetary space. The underlying physical mechanisms, such as plasma instabilities and magnetic reconnection, are relevant also in laboratory plasmas, and are believed to be responsible for eruptive activity on other stars and astrophysical objects. However, the detailed ways in which these mechanisms work in these seemingly different environments are not yet well understood.

The purpose of this collaborative project was to approach the problem of solar eruptive activity simultaneously from three different perspectives, by using ground-based and spacecraft observations, numerical modeling, and laboratory experiments. Our responsibility was to design, run, and analyze magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) numerical  simulations that are inspired by, and can be directly compared to, solar observations and laboratory experiments. MHD simulations can provide only a simplified version of reality, but they have the advantage that they can provide some physical quantities (such as the three-dimensional magnetic field) that are difficult, sometimes even impossible, to measure in sufficient detail in observations or laboratory experiments.    
The main results obtained during the course of the project can be summarized as follows. 

(1) We demonstrated in numerical experiments that the continuous twisting of a magnetic flux rope by vortex flows (corresponding to the rotation of sunspots) leads to a linear increase of the total electric current and to an expansion and rise of the rope at a constant acceleration rate. In the later phase of the twisting, however, the total current starts to saturate and a more rapid upward acceleration of the flux rope commences. This confirms the laboratory experiments by Stenson and Bellan (Physical Review Letters 109, 075001, 2012), and it concurs with the transition of slow rise to a rapid acceleration that is often observed in CMEs. 

(2) In collaboration with researchers from Paris Observatory and Potsdam University, we employed numerical simulations to show that the often postulated current-neutralization of solar active regions breaks down as soon as magnetic shear develops along the polarity inversion line (PIL) that divides the two magnetic polarities (positive and negative) of the region (Dalmasse et al., 2015). Such shear (i.e., magnetic field aligned with the PIL) is typically observed in active regions that produce CMEs, indicating that CMEs stem from magnetic fields that carry a net (non-neutralized) electric current. In order to support this result we analyzed, in collaboration with researchers from Stanford University and NASA/GSFC, observations of four active regions and found that the two regions that produced CMEs were indeed characterized by a strong net current, while the remaining two non-CME-productive regions were almost perfectly current-neutralized. This suggest that the degree of current-neutralization may serve as a proxy for forecasting the ability of active regions to produce CMEs (Liu et al., 2017). A comparison of a CME-productive and a non-CME-productive active region is shown in Figure 1.       

(3) Based on idealized numerical simulations of CMEs and their interplanetary counterparts (ICMEs), we suggested a mechanism that potentially effects the trajectory of such events. We found that if an ICME travels in a radial background magnetic field, the Lorentz forces that result from the interaction of electric current present in the ICME and the background field deflect the top of the ICME out of its plane of propagation. While the underlying physics is similar, this is not the same effect as the often observed rotation of solar filaments or CMEs about their rise direction. Our result is potentially relevant for the forecasting of the magnetic orientation of ICMEs, but it is not yet clear how strong the deflection can get in real ICMEs, where the electric currents are less compact than in our idealized models. This has yet to be clarified using more advanced simulations and observations. Figure 2 shows an example of a simulation in which the deflection of the ICME top can be seen.
